elements.content: Two pairs of Cd(II)-5-aminotetrazolate coordination complexes, {[Cd(5-HATZ)2(H2O)2(μ2-SO4)]·H2O} n (1a) and [Cd5(5-ATZ)4(μ3-OH)2(μ5-SO4)2] n (1b), [Cd(5-HATZ)2(μ2-Cl)2] n (2a), and [Cd3(5-ATZ)4(MeCN)2(μ2-Cl)2] n (2b), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. At room temperature 1D single-bridged and double-bridged chain-like compounds 1a and 2a were isolated by solution evaporation method. Under hydrothermal synthesis at 180 °C, two three-dimensional coordination polymers 1b and 2b were isolated from compounds 1a and 2a, respectively. 1b is constructed by 3D [Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n 4+ network templated by 5-ATZ anions. 2b exhibits the 3D metal-organic framework with a (8.122)(844.122)(42.124) topology. 5-Aminotetrazolate is a terminal ligand in 1a and 2a, whereas it is three-coordinated and/or four-coordinated in 1b and 2b. Thermal studies show that high-dimensional structures have higher thermal stability than that of 1D structures.
elements.clean_text: Two pairs of Cd(II)-5-aminotetrazolate coordination complexes, {[Cd(5-HATZ)2(H2O)2(μ2-SO4)]⋅H2O} n  (1a) and [Cd5(5-ATZ)4(μ3-OH)2(μ5-SO4)2] n  (1b), [Cd(5-HATZ)2(μ2-Cl)2] n  (2a), and [Cd3(5-ATZ)4(MeCN)2(μ2-Cl)2] n  (2b), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. At room temperature 1D single-bridged and double-bridged chain-like compounds 1a and 2a were isolated by solution evaporation method. Under hydrothermal synthesis at 180 °C, two three-dimensional coordination polymers 1b and 2b were isolated from compounds 1a and 2a, respectively. 1b is constructed by 3D [Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n  4+ network templated by 5-ATZ anions. 2b exhibits the 3D metal-organic framework with a (8.122)(844.122)(42.124) topology. 5-Aminotetrazolate is a terminal ligand in 1a and 2a, whereas it is three-coordinated and/or four-coordinated in 1b and 2b. Thermal studies show that high-dimensional structures have higher thermal stability than that of 1D structures.

elements.content: Two pairs of Cd(II)-5-aminotetrazolate coordination polymers have been synthesized under room temperature and hydrothermal conditions. With increasing reaction temperature, ligands exhibit a higher connectivity level and the structures vary from 1D chains to 3D frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Two pairs of Cd(II)-5-aminotetrazolate coordination polymers have been synthesized under room temperature and hydrothermal conditions. With increasing reaction temperature, ligands exhibit a higher connectivity level and the structures vary from 1D chains to 3D frameworks.

elements.content: The synthesis of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) is of great interest and importance in producing new functional materials with desired magnetic, catalytic, electric, and fluorescent properties as well as potential applications in ion exchange and gas storage. However, it is still a challenging task to explore successful synthetic strategies for the preparation of the MOFs that have predictable structures and applications. These preparations are highly influenced by factors such as the solvent system, temperature, and pH value of the solution. Considering that, it is reasonable that understanding and insight into the preparation process can be obtained by carrying out a special study by only changing one of the subtle reaction conditions. From the entropic point of view, high dimensional coordination polymers often exhibit important functionality that low dimensional structures are lacking. The tendency of mixtures of metal ions and complementary organic ligands to form poly nuclear aggregates at solvothermal conditions is well-known in the literature. Synthesis at a higher temperature could avoid the coordination of a terminal ligand resulting in the formation of polymer frameworks with high dimensionality.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is of great interest and importance in producing new functional materials with desired magnetic, catalytic, electric, and fluorescent properties as well as potential applications in ion exchange and gas storage. However, it is still a challenging task to explore successful synthetic strategies for the preparation of the MOFs that have predictable structures and applications. These preparations are highly influenced by factors such as the solvent system, temperature, and pH value of the solution. Considering that, it is reasonable that understanding and insight into the preparation process can be obtained by carrying out a special study by only changing one of the subtle reaction conditions. From the entropic point of view, high dimensional coordination polymers often exhibit important functionality that low dimensional structures are lacking. The tendency of mixtures of metal ions and complementary organic ligands to form poly nuclear aggregates at solvothermal conditions is well-known in the literature. Synthesis at a higher temperature could avoid the coordination of a terminal ligand resulting in the formation of polymer frameworks with high dimensionality.

elements.content: On the other hand, 5-aminotetrazolate (5-HATZ) is a multidentate organic ligand that potentially possesses the capability to bridge metal atoms in various coordination modes with the nitrogen atoms of the tetrazole ring. Controlling reaction temperature, it can exist as neutral ligand or anionic ligand by losing the hydrogen atom attached to the tetrazole ring. So it is helpful to investigate the temperature effect on the formation of coordination networks. The d10 configuration and softness of cadmium(II) permit a wide variety of geometries and coordination numbers. Therefore, in this work, we have synthesized two pairs of novel coordination polymers based on the reaction of 5-HATZ and cadmium(II) ions under room temperature and hydrothermal condition, {[Cd(5-HATZ)2(H2O)2(μ2-SO4)]·H2O} n (1a), [Cd5(5-ATZ)4(μ3-OH)2(μ5-SO4)2] n (1b), [Cd(5-HATZ)2(μ2-Cl)2] n (2a) and [Cd3(5-ATZ)4(MeCN)2(μ2-Cl)2] n (2b). As shown in Scheme , 1a and 2a were synthesized at room temperature, which at high-T the components might recrystallize in a different form. Using hydrothermal techniques we successfully synthesized complexes 1b and 2b at higher temperature based on compounds 1a and 2a, respectively.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, 5-aminotetrazolate (5-HATZ) is a multidentate organic ligand that potentially possesses the capability to bridge metal atoms in various coordination modes with the nitrogen atoms of the tetrazole ring. Controlling reaction temperature, it can exist as neutral ligand or anionic ligand by losing the hydrogen atom attached to the tetrazole ring. So it is helpful to investigate the temperature effect on the formation of coordination networks. The d10 configuration and softness of cadmium(II) permit a wide variety of geometries and coordination numbers. Therefore, in this work, we have synthesized two pairs of novel coordination polymers based on the reaction of 5-HATZ and cadmium(II) ions under room temperature and hydrothermal condition, {[Cd(5-HATZ)2(H2O)2(μ2-SO4)]⋅H2O} n  (1a), [Cd5(5-ATZ)4(μ3-OH)2(μ5-SO4)2] n  (1b), [Cd(5-HATZ)2(μ2-Cl)2] n  (2a) and [Cd3(5-ATZ)4(MeCN)2(μ2-Cl)2] n  (2b). As shown in Scheme , 1a and 2a were synthesized at room temperature, which at high-T the components might recrystallize in a different form. Using hydrothermal techniques we successfully synthesized complexes 1b and 2b at higher temperature based on compounds 1a and 2a, respectively.

Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna-IR 560 Infrared spectrometer in the 4000−400 cm−1 region. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were recorded on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. TGA experiments were performed on a NETZSCH TG 209 instrument with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The photoluminescence spectrum was measured by a F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Characterization

Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna-IR 560 Infrared spectrometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were recorded on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. TGA experiments were performed on a NETZSCH TG 209 instrument with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. The photoluminescence spectrum was measured by a F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (10 mL) of 3CdSO4·8H2O (0.77 g, 1 mmol) was added into an aqueous solution (50 mL) of 5-HATZ (0.51 g, 6 mmol) with stirring at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting solution was filtered, and left to evaporate. After a week, colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractrion were obtained (0.30 g, yield 70% based on 3CdSO4·8H2O). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C2H12CdN10O7S: C, 5.55; H, 2.77; N, 32.36%. Found: C, 5.39; H, 2.88; N, 31.64%. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3397 s, 3318 m, 3208 m, 3123 m, 1652 s, 1577 m, 1441 m, 1292 m, 1188 m, 1115 m, 1059 m, 1006 w, 765 w, 724 m, 678 w, 619 m, 437 m.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Cd(5-HATZ)2(H2O)2(μ2-SO4)]⋅H2O} n  (1a)

An aqueous solution (10 mL) of 3CdSO4⋅8H2O (0.77 g, 1 mmol) was added into an aqueous solution (50 mL) of 5-HATZ (0.51 g, 6 mmol) with stirring at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting solution was filtered, and left to evaporate. After a week, colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractrion were obtained (0.30 g, yield 70% based on 3CdSO4⋅8H2O). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C2H12CdN10O7S: C, 5.55; H, 2.77; N, 32.36%. Found: C, 5.39; H, 2.88; N, 31.64%. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) = 3397 s, 3318 m, 3208 m, 3123 m, 1652 s, 1577 m, 1441 m, 1292 m, 1188 m, 1115 m, 1059 m, 1006 w, 765 w, 724 m, 678 w, 619 m, 437 m.

elements.content: Compound 1b was synthesized from compound 1a (0.15 g) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor (10 mL water), under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1b were obtained (0.05 g, yield: 64% based on Cd(II) in 1a). Anal. Calcd for C4H10Cd5N20O10S2: C, 4.27; H, 0.90; N, 24.91%. Found: C, 4.13; H, 1.05; N, 24.38%. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3424 m, 3341 m, 3233 w, 1644 m, 1624 m, 1557 s, 1545 s, 1437 m, 1420 m, 1279 m, 1254 m, 1123 s, 1076 m, 989 m, 894 m, 798 m, 773 m, 744 m, 613 s, 459 m. Compound 1b can also be obtained by direct mixture of 3CdSO4·8H2O (0.08 g, 0.1 mmol) and 5-HATZ (0.03 g, 0.3 mmol) under the hydrothermal condition with 45% based on metal salts.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cd5(5-ATZ)4(μ3-OH)2(μ5-SO4)2] n  (1b)

Compound 1b was synthesized from compound 1a (0.15 g) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor (10 mL water), under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1b were obtained (0.05 g, yield: 64% based on Cd(II) in 1a). Anal. Calcd for C4H10Cd5N20O10S2: C, 4.27; H, 0.90; N, 24.91%. Found: C, 4.13; H, 1.05; N, 24.38%. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) = 3424 m, 3341 m, 3233 w, 1644 m, 1624 m, 1557 s, 1545 s, 1437 m, 1420 m, 1279 m, 1254 m, 1123 s, 1076 m, 989 m, 894 m, 798 m, 773 m, 744 m, 613 s, 459 m. Compound 1b can also be obtained by direct mixture of 3CdSO4⋅8H2O (0.08 g, 0.1 mmol) and 5-HATZ (0.03 g, 0.3 mmol) under the hydrothermal condition with 45% based on metal salts.

elements.content: A mixture of CdCl2·2.5H2O (0.46 g, 2 mmol), 5-HATZ (0.34 g, 4 mmol), MeCN (10 mL), and water (30 mL) was stirred for 4 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was filtered and then left to evaporate. After a week, colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffracion were obtained (0.27 g, yield 75% based on CdCl2·2.5H2O). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C2H6CdCl2N10: C, 6.80; H, 1.71; N, 39.63%. Found: C, 6.09; H, 2.70; N, 38.88%. Synthesis of [Cd(5-HATZ)2(μ2-Cl)2] n  (2a)

A mixture of CdCl2⋅2.5H2O (0.46 g, 2 mmol), 5-HATZ (0.34 g, 4 mmol), MeCN (10 mL), and water (30 mL) was stirred for 4 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was filtered and then left to evaporate. After a week, colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffracion were obtained (0.27 g, yield 75% based on CdCl2⋅2.5H2O). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C2H6CdCl2N10: C, 6.80; H, 1.71; N, 39.63%. Found: C, 6.09; H, 2.70; N, 38.88%. elements.content: Compound 2b was synthesized from compound 2a (0.10 g) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor (2.5 mL MeCN, 7.5 mL water), under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 2b were obtained (0.06 g, yield: 38% based on Cd(II) in 2a). Anal. Calcd for C8H14Cd3Cl2N22: C, 11.63; H, 1.71; N, 37.28%. Found: C, 10.97; H, 2.05; N, 36.44%. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3444 s, 3342 s, 2300 m, 2271 m, 1653 m, 1620 s, 1556 s, 1462 m, 1438 s, 1283 m, 1163 m, 1130 m, 1084 m, 1014 m, 753 m, 450 m. Compound 2b can also be obtained by direct mixture of CdCl2·2.5H2O (0.05 g, 0.2 mmol) and 5-HATZ (0.04 g, 0.4 mmol) under the hydrothermal condition with 31% based on metal salts.

Synthesis of [Cd3(5-ATZ)4(MeCN)2(μ2-Cl)2] n  (2b)

Compound 2b was synthesized from compound 2a (0.10 g) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor (2.5 mL MeCN, 7.5 mL water), under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 2b were obtained (0.06 g, yield: 38% based on Cd(II) in 2a). Anal. Calcd for C8H14Cd3Cl2N22: C, 11.63; H, 1.71; N, 37.28%. Found: C, 10.97; H, 2.05; N, 36.44%. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) = 3444 s, 3342 s, 2300 m, 2271 m, 1653 m, 1620 s, 1556 s, 1462 m, 1438 s, 1283 m, 1163 m, 1130 m, 1084 m, 1014 m, 753 m, 450 m. Compound 2b can also be obtained by direct mixture of CdCl2⋅2.5H2O (0.05 g, 0.2 mmol) and 5-HATZ (0.04 g, 0.4 mmol) under the hydrothermal condition with 31% based on metal salts.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of compounds 1a−2b were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. Accurate unit cell parameters were determined by a least-squares fit of 2θ values, and intensity data were measured on a Bruker Smart CCD or Rigaku Raxis Rapid IP diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The crystallographic data and selected bonded lengths and angles for 1a−2b are listed in and .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Suitable single crystals of compounds 1a-2b were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. Accurate unit cell parameters were determined by a least-squares fit of 2θ values, and intensity data were measured on a Bruker Smart CCD or Rigaku Raxis Rapid IP diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The crystallographic data and selected bonded lengths and angles for 1a-2b are listed in  and .

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1a is a 1D zigzag chain of Cd(II) ions, and each metal ion shows a coordination number of six, binding with two 5-ATZ ligands, two bridging sulfate O atoms, and two water molecules [CdN 2.301(3)−2.307(4) Å, CdO 2.311(1)−2.390(1) Å] (Figure a). The sulfate anions not only act as bridging ligands but also form various hydrogen bonds. In the ac plane, the terminal amino group and the adjacent noncoordinated N atom of each 5-ATZ donate H atoms to sulfate O atoms from adjacent chain generate intermolecular N−H···O (2.949(6) Å and 2.787(6) Å) hydrogen bonding interactions. In addition, hydrogen bonds also exist between solvent water and the sulfate oxygen or noncoordinated tetrazole N atom. As a result, 1D zigzag chains extend to a 2D layer with the intermolecular Cd···Cd distance of 8.047(11) and 7.941(3) Å (a). Then, the 2D layers are further assembled into a 3D network by hydrogen bonds among the coordinated waters, sulfate oxygen atoms and solvent waters (b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1a is a 1D zigzag chain of Cd(II) ions, and each metal ion shows a coordination number of six, binding with two 5-ATZ ligands, two bridging sulfate O atoms, and two water molecules [CdN 2.301(3)-2.307(4) Å, CdO 2.311(1)-2.390(1) Å] (Figure a). The sulfate anions not only act as bridging ligands but also form various hydrogen bonds. In the ac plane, the terminal amino group and the adjacent noncoordinated N atom of each 5-ATZ donate H atoms to sulfate O atoms from adjacent chain generate intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅O (2.949(6) Å and 2.787(6) Å) hydrogen bonding interactions. In addition, hydrogen bonds also exist between solvent water and the sulfate oxygen or noncoordinated tetrazole N atom. As a result, 1D zigzag chains extend to a 2D layer with the intermolecular Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance of 8.047(11) and 7.941(3) Å (a). Then, the 2D layers are further assembled into a 3D network by hydrogen bonds among the coordinated waters, sulfate oxygen atoms and solvent waters (b).

elements.content: (a) View of the one-dimensional chain in 1a; (b) The three-dimensional structure of 1b. Key: Cd, purple; C, dark gray; N, blue; O, red; S, yellow.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the one-dimensional chain in 1a; (b) The three-dimensional structure of 1b. Key: Cd, purple; C, dark gray; N, blue; O, red; S, yellow.

elements.content: Hydrothermal techniques provide high reaction temperature and show us some great advantages over other methods for the synthesis of high-dimensional coordination compounds, so 3D 1b was crystallized under hydrothermal condition based on compound 1a (Figure b). X-ray crystallography reveals that all the Cd(II) ions are hexacoordinated and there are three crystallographically independent Cd(II) centers in an asymmetric unit. As illustrated in Figure , Cd1 adopts a octahedral coordination environment that are formed by four oxygen atoms located at an equatorial plane and two nitrogen atoms at the axial positions [Cd1−N 2.303(13) Å, Cd1−O 2.272(42)−2.293(16) Å]. It is noticeable that the bond angles around the Cd1 center [N7−Cd1−N7B, O4− Cd1− O4C and O5B−Cd1−O5D] are all 180° and the coordination atoms around Cd1 is centrosymmetric. In contrast, Cd2 exhibits distorted octahedral geometry, which is coordinated by three tetrazolate nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from two sulfate anions together with one oxygen atom from the hydroxyl groups [Cd2−N 2.349(5)−2.568(17) Å, Cd2−O 2.260(19)−2.278(7) Å]. The Cd3A center presents a highly distorted octahedron, defined by three nitrogen atoms from three different tetrazolate groups and two oxygen atoms from two sulfate anions and one hydroxyl group [Cd3A−N 2.285(31)−2.354(7) Å, Cd3A−O 2.279(15)−2.478(4) Å].
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal techniques provide high reaction temperature and show us some great advantages over other methods for the synthesis of high-dimensional coordination compounds, so 3D 1b was crystallized under hydrothermal condition based on compound 1a (Figure b). X-ray crystallography reveals that all the Cd(II) ions are hexacoordinated and there are three crystallographically independent Cd(II) centers in an asymmetric unit. As illustrated in Figure , Cd1 adopts a octahedral coordination environment that are formed by four oxygen atoms located at an equatorial plane and two nitrogen atoms at the axial positions [Cd1-N 2.303(13) Å, Cd1-O 2.272(42)-2.293(16) Å]. It is noticeable that the bond angles around the Cd1 center [N7-Cd1-N7B, O4- Cd1- O4C and O5B-Cd1-O5D] are all 180° and the coordination atoms around Cd1 is centrosymmetric. In contrast, Cd2 exhibits distorted octahedral geometry, which is coordinated by three tetrazolate nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from two sulfate anions together with one oxygen atom from the hydroxyl groups [Cd2-N 2.349(5)-2.568(17) Å, Cd2-O 2.260(19)-2.278(7) Å]. The Cd3A center presents a highly distorted octahedron, defined by three nitrogen atoms from three different tetrazolate groups and two oxygen atoms from two sulfate anions and one hydroxyl group [Cd3A-N 2.285(31)-2.354(7) Å, Cd3A-O 2.279(15)-2.478(4) Å].

elements.content: Coordination environment of the Cd atoms in 1b.
elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination environment of the Cd atoms in 1b.

elements.content: It should be noted that only one crystallographically independent SO4 2− anion exists in complex 1b, and each sulfate ligand adopts μ5-bridging mode in which there are one μ2-bridging oxygen atom and three monodentate coordination oxygen atoms. The Cd atoms are connected by μ5-sulfate anions associated with μ3-OH units resulting in a 3D purely inorganic cationic [Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n 4+ network, whereas 5-ATZ ligands as organic anions adopt μ3- and μ4-coordinated modes (Figure b) and occupy the remaining sites on Cd atoms to complete the overall 3D network (Figure b). Recently, Li et al. reported [Cd2(pzta)(OH)(SO4)] n [pzta = pyrazinyl tetrazolate] (1c). Intriguingly, though the sulfate anions and hydroxyl groups have the same coordination modes in compounds 1b and 1c, they exhibit two completely different 3D Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n 4+ networks. As shown in Figure a, two μ2-bridging oxygen atoms of different sulfate anions double bridge with two Cd atoms in 1b, whereas the oxygen atoms alternately bridge three Cd atoms in 1c. The differences may be attributed to stereochemical effects of 5-aminotetrazolate and pyrazinyl tetrazolate in the crystal self-assembly process.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that only one crystallographically independent SO4 2- anion exists in complex 1b, and each sulfate ligand adopts μ5-bridging mode in which there are one μ2-bridging oxygen atom and three monodentate coordination oxygen atoms. The Cd atoms are connected by μ5-sulfate anions associated with μ3-OH units resulting in a 3D purely inorganic cationic [Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n  4+ network, whereas 5-ATZ ligands as organic anions adopt μ3- and μ4-coordinated modes (Figure b) and occupy the remaining sites on Cd atoms to complete the overall 3D network (Figure b). Recently, Li et al. reported [Cd2(pzta)(OH)(SO4)] n  [pzta = pyrazinyl tetrazolate] (1c). Intriguingly, though the sulfate anions and hydroxyl groups have the same coordination modes in compounds 1b and 1c, they exhibit two completely different 3D Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n  4+ networks. As shown in Figure a, two μ2-bridging oxygen atoms of different sulfate anions double bridge with two Cd atoms in 1b, whereas the oxygen atoms alternately bridge three Cd atoms in 1c. The differences may be attributed to stereochemical effects of 5-aminotetrazolate and pyrazinyl tetrazolate in the crystal self-assembly process.

elements.content: (a) View of the 3D purely inorganic cationic subnet in 1b (left) and 1c (right) along the b axis; (b) The μ3 and μ4 coordinated modes of the 5-aminotetrazole ligand in 1b. Key: Cd, purple; C, dark gray; N, blue; O, cyan; S, yellow, SO4 2−, polyhedron.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) View of the 3D purely inorganic cationic subnet in 1b (left) and 1c (right) along the b axis; (b) The μ3 and μ4 coordinated modes of the 5-aminotetrazole ligand in 1b. Key: Cd, purple; C, dark gray; N, blue; O, cyan; S, yellow, SO4 2-, polyhedron.

elements.content: As compared to 1a, all of the Cd atoms in 1b are coordinated by other moieties instead of water molecules. In this study, sulfate anions acting as bridging ligands exhibit two kinds of coordinated modes, whereas 5-HATZ ligands vary from terminal coordination ligands to multidentate bridging anions, all of which result in a significant difference between their structures.
elements.clean_text: As compared to 1a, all of the Cd atoms in 1b are coordinated by other moieties instead of water molecules. In this study, sulfate anions acting as bridging ligands exhibit two kinds of coordinated modes, whereas 5-HATZ ligands vary from terminal coordination ligands to multidentate bridging anions, all of which result in a significant difference between their structures.

elements.content: Complex 2a contains a double-bridged 1D chain (Figure a). Each Cd(II) node takes a tetragonal-bipyramidal geometry coordinated by four μ2-Cl anions and two 5-ATZ ligands. The terminal amino groups of each 5-ATZ ligand donate H atoms to the adjacent coordinated Cl atoms to generate intramolecular N−H···Cl (3.289(16) Å) hydrogen bond (the sum of the van der Waals radii for H and Cl is 3.0 Å). And the terminal amino group also associates with the other three noncoordinated nitrogen atoms in the same 5-ATZ ligand to form intermolecular N−H···N (2.860(28) Å and 3.051(17) Å) hydrogen bonding interactions (). Therefore, a 3D supramolecular framework is formed.
elements.clean_text: Complex 2a contains a double-bridged 1D chain (Figure a). Each Cd(II) node takes a tetragonal-bipyramidal geometry coordinated by four μ2-Cl anions and two 5-ATZ ligands. The terminal amino groups of each 5-ATZ ligand donate H atoms to the adjacent coordinated Cl atoms to generate intramolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl (3.289(16) Å) hydrogen bond (the sum of the van der Waals radii for H and Cl is 3.0 Å). And the terminal amino group also associates with the other three noncoordinated nitrogen atoms in the same 5-ATZ ligand to form intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅N (2.860(28) Å and 3.051(17) Å) hydrogen bonding interactions (). Therefore, a 3D supramolecular framework is formed.

elements.content: As shown in Figure b, compound 2b was created under solvothermal condition based on compound 2a. In the 3D structure of 2b, the basic unit is composed of trinuclear cadmium cations, bridged by μ2-Cl atoms (Figure ). There are two crystallographically independent Cd atoms in 2b. Cd1 is six coordinated by one μ2-Cl atom and five nitrogen atoms with a distorted octahedron. Bond length of the nitrogen atom from MeCN [Cd1−N 2.420(4) Å] is slightly larger than that of the others from 5-ATZ anions [Cd1N 2.319(2)−2.350(2) Å]. The coordination environment around Cd2 atom is an elongate octahedron with four nitrogen atoms from different 5-ATZ anions at a square plane and two μ2-Cl atoms at the axial positions [Cd2−N 2.335(2) Å, Cd2−Cl 2.664(1) Å]. The Cd···Cd distance in the trinuclear unit is 3.847(1) Å. In the structure, all 5-ATZ ligands adopt μ3-bridged modes. Each 5-ATZ anion uses N1 and N4 to link Cd1 atoms forming a 2D layer. And the 5-ATZ anion further uses N2 to link Cd2 atom, while Cd2 atom uses two coordinated μ2-Cl atoms to link two Cd1 atoms. Thus, the adjacent 2D Cd1 layers are linked to form a 3D network. From the topological point of view, the intricate 3D framework of compound 2b can be specified by the Schläfli symbol (8.122)(84.122)(42.124) in which the 5-ATZ anions and Cd(II) centers are regarded as three- and four-connected nodes, respectively ().
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure b, compound 2b was created under solvothermal condition based on compound 2a. In the 3D structure of 2b, the basic unit is composed of trinuclear cadmium cations, bridged by μ2-Cl atoms (Figure ). There are two crystallographically independent Cd atoms in 2b. Cd1 is six coordinated by one μ2-Cl atom and five nitrogen atoms with a distorted octahedron. Bond length of the nitrogen atom from MeCN [Cd1-N 2.420(4) Å] is slightly larger than that of the others from 5-ATZ anions [Cd1N 2.319(2)-2.350(2) Å]. The coordination environment around Cd2 atom is an elongate octahedron with four nitrogen atoms from different 5-ATZ anions at a square plane and two μ2-Cl atoms at the axial positions [Cd2-N 2.335(2) Å, Cd2-Cl 2.664(1) Å]. The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance in the trinuclear unit is 3.847(1) Å. In the structure, all 5-ATZ ligands adopt μ3-bridged modes. Each 5-ATZ anion uses N1 and N4 to link Cd1 atoms forming a 2D layer. And the 5-ATZ anion further uses N2 to link Cd2 atom, while Cd2 atom uses two coordinated μ2-Cl atoms to link two Cd1 atoms. Thus, the adjacent 2D Cd1 layers are linked to form a 3D network. From the topological point of view, the intricate 3D framework of compound 2b can be specified by the Schläfli symbol (8.122)(84.122)(42.124) in which the 5-ATZ anions and Cd(II) centers are regarded as three- and four-connected nodes, respectively ().

elements.content: Coordination environment of the Cd atoms in 2b.
elements.clean_text: 5  Coordination environment of the Cd atoms in 2b.

elements.content: Herein, we present a method for preparing homoligand 3D coordination polymers from 1D chained precursors without further addition of 5-HATZ or other organic ligands, which is slightly different from previous reported two-step synthesis in MOFs based on addition of organic ligands in the second step. The successful synthesis of complexes 1b and 2b is supported by the following reasons. First, the Cd(II) ion is flexible in adopting different coordination geometries and its coordination bonds are prone to cleavage and formation. Second, tetrazole species possess the capability to bridge metal atoms in various coordination modes with nitrogen atoms of the aromatic ring. Third, hydrothermal techniques provide a condition to make 1a and 1b recrystallize at high temperature and to deprotonate tetrazole species, which results in them recrystallizing in different forms. Though both complexes 1b and 2b can also be obtained by the direct mixture of the starting materials, the structural transfer starting from low-dimensional complexes based on hydrothermal conditions represents a new assay to construct to high-dimensional materials. The extension work to hydrothermally synthesize high-dimensional complexes based on low-dimensional complexes as agents is currently underway.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present a method for preparing homoligand 3D coordination polymers from 1D chained precursors without further addition of 5-HATZ or other organic ligands, which is slightly different from previous reported two-step synthesis in MOFs based on addition of organic ligands in the second step. The successful synthesis of complexes 1b and 2b is supported by the following reasons. First, the Cd(II) ion is flexible in adopting different coordination geometries and its coordination bonds are prone to cleavage and formation. Second, tetrazole species possess the capability to bridge metal atoms in various coordination modes with nitrogen atoms of the aromatic ring. Third, hydrothermal techniques provide a condition to make 1a and 1b recrystallize at high temperature and to deprotonate tetrazole species, which results in them recrystallizing in different forms. Though both complexes 1b and 2b can also be obtained by the direct mixture of the starting materials, the structural transfer starting from low-dimensional complexes based on hydrothermal conditions represents a new assay to construct to high-dimensional materials. The extension work to hydrothermally synthesize high-dimensional complexes based on low-dimensional complexes as agents is currently underway.

elements.content: As shown in , the IR spectra of compounds 1a−2b exhibit strong characteristic absorptions around 3300−3500 cm−1 for the amino groups. All of them show two distinctive ν(NH) stretching bands (1a 3397 and 3318 cm−1; 1b 3424 and 3341 cm−1; 2a 3396 and 3319 cm−1; 2b 3444 and 3342 cm−1) and shift from the bands observed at 3483 and 3381 cm−1 for the free ligand. 1a and 2a have a further shift than 1b and 2b to low wavenumbers, which can be attributed to the hydrogen bonding interactions of amino group existing in 1a and 2a. Besides these, the strong band around 1652 cm−1 splits into two bands and the medium band around 1577 cm−1 becomes strong when the 5-HATZ ligand vary from terminal coordination ligand to multidentate bridging anion. All these bands associate with ν(CN)/ring stretching vibrations plus δ(N−H)NH,NH2 of the ligand. The free SO4 2− under perfect T d symmetry exhibits four internal vibrations: ν1(A1), the symmetric S−O stretching mode, ν2 (E), the symmetric SO4 bending modes, ν3 (F2) and ν4 (F2), the asymmetric S−O stretching and SO4 bending modes, respectively. In 1a, the SO4 2− is bidentate bridging coordination, so the symmetry is lowered from T d to C 2v . The IR bands at 1059−1142 cm−1, therefore, may be attributable to the ν3 modes. The bands/shoulders at ∼566, ∼619, and ∼678 cm−1 may be assigned to the ν4 modes, with the higher wavenumber band being superimposed by a ligand vibration. The bands at ∼1006 and ∼437 cm−1 may be assigned to the ν1 and ν2 modes, respectively. In 1b, the SO4 2− adopts a μ5 coordination mode and leads to a low site symmetry C 1. The bands in the region of 1200−990 cm−1 correspond to the ν3 and ν1 modes, and 650−550 and 500−430 cm−1 may be attributed to ν4 and ν2 modes, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Properties

As shown in , the IR spectra of compounds 1a-2b exhibit strong characteristic absorptions around 3300-3500 cm-1 for the amino groups. All of them show two distinctive ν(NH) stretching bands (1a 3397 and 3318 cm-1; 1b 3424 and 3341 cm-1; 2a 3396 and 3319 cm-1; 2b 3444 and 3342 cm-1) and shift from the bands observed at 3483 and 3381 cm-1 for the free ligand. 1a and 2a have a further shift than 1b and 2b to low wavenumbers, which can be attributed to the hydrogen bonding interactions of amino group existing in 1a and 2a. Besides these, the strong band around 1652 cm-1 splits into two bands and the medium band around 1577 cm-1 becomes strong when the 5-HATZ ligand vary from terminal coordination ligand to multidentate bridging anion. All these bands associate with ν(CN)/ring stretching vibrations plus δ(N-H)NH,NH2  of the ligand. The free SO4 2- under perfect T  d  symmetry exhibits four internal vibrations: ν1(A1), the symmetric S-O stretching mode, ν2 (E), the symmetric SO4 bending modes, ν3 (F2) and ν4 (F2), the asymmetric S-O stretching and SO4 bending modes, respectively. In 1a, the SO4 2- is bidentate bridging coordination, so the symmetry is lowered from T  d  to C 2v . The IR bands at 1059-1142 cm-1, therefore, may be attributable to the ν3 modes. The bands/shoulders at ~566, ~619, and ~678 cm-1 may be assigned to the ν4 modes, with the higher wavenumber band being superimposed by a ligand vibration. The bands at ~1006 and ~437 cm-1 may be assigned to the ν1 and ν2 modes, respectively. In 1b, the SO4 2- adopts a μ5 coordination mode and leads to a low site symmetry C 1. The bands in the region of 1200-990 cm-1 correspond to the ν3 and ν1 modes, and 650-550 and 500-430 cm-1 may be attributed to ν4 and ν2 modes, respectively.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties for compounds 1a−2b were investigated in the solid state, and only 1b has luminescence (). It can be observed that the compound 1b exhibits photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 275 nm, which may be due to the unique coordination network in 1b.
elements.clean_text: The photoluminescent properties for compounds 1a-2b were investigated in the solid state, and only 1b has luminescence (). It can be observed that the compound 1b exhibits photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 275 nm, which may be due to the unique coordination network in 1b.

elements.content: Thermogravimeric analysis of 1a (Figure ) shows 12.3% weight loss between room temperature and 147 °C, in agreement with the corresponding calculated values of 12.5%, due to the loss of water molecules. The distinction between weight losses from the coordinated and noncoordinated water was not clearly demonstrated in TGA data. The relatively low temperature for loss of coordinated water molecules demonstrates their weak coordination. Then the continuous weight loses above 195 °C correspond to the continuous decomposition of 5-HATZ ligands and anions. For 2a, there is no weight loss from room temperature to 258 °C, and after that, it begins to decompose quickly. Compared with 1a and 2a, 3D complexes 1b and 2b exhibit remarkable higher thermalstability. The TGA study of 1b shows no weight loss from room temperature to 390 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. Above 390 °C, the weight loss is due to the collapse of the framework. Furthermore, the high density value (ρ = 3.392 g/cm3) also supports the high thermal stability of the 3D framework. The TGA data for 2b indicates the first weight loss occurs at ca. 239 °C and the second started at ca. 358 °C. For all complexes, complete decomposition is not achieved above 600 °C. The TGA results show that normally the 1D complexes are more unstable than 3D complexes, and the 3D complexes normally show high robustness for the coordination networks, which is consistent with the previous reported result. The simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 2b are shown in a and . They are in good agreement with each other, which prove the phase purity of the as-synthesized product. The results of a series of varied temperature PXRD of 2b from 100 to 300 °C exhibit no phase transformation and the coordination network variety ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties and PXRD

Thermogravimeric analysis of 1a (Figure ) shows 12.3% weight loss between room temperature and 147 °C, in agreement with the corresponding calculated values of 12.5%, due to the loss of water molecules. The distinction between weight losses from the coordinated and noncoordinated water was not clearly demonstrated in TGA data. The relatively low temperature for loss of coordinated water molecules demonstrates their weak coordination. Then the continuous weight loses above 195 °C correspond to the continuous decomposition of 5-HATZ ligands and anions. For 2a, there is no weight loss from room temperature to 258 °C, and after that, it begins to decompose quickly. Compared with 1a and 2a, 3D complexes 1b and 2b exhibit remarkable higher thermalstability. The TGA study of 1b shows no weight loss from room temperature to 390 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. Above 390 °C, the weight loss is due to the collapse of the framework. Furthermore, the high density value (ρ = 3.392 g/cm3) also supports the high thermal stability of the 3D framework. The TGA data for 2b indicates the first weight loss occurs at ca. 239 °C and the second started at ca. 358 °C. For all complexes, complete decomposition is not achieved above 600 °C. The TGA results show that normally the 1D complexes are more unstable than 3D complexes, and the 3D complexes normally show high robustness for the coordination networks, which is consistent with the previous reported result. The simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 2b are shown in a and . They are in good agreement with each other, which prove the phase purity of the as-synthesized product. The results of a series of varied temperature PXRD of 2b from 100 to 300 °C exhibit no phase transformation and the coordination network variety ().

elements.content: TGA curves for compounds 1a−2b.
elements.clean_text: 6  TGA curves for compounds 1a-2b.

elements.content: Two pairs of Cd(II)-5-aminotetrazolate coordination polymers from 1D to 3D materials were successfully isolated in this study. 1a and 2a are 1D chains synthesized by the solution evaporation method at room temperature, while 1b and 2b are 3D frameworks synthesized under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. 1b is constructed by 3D inorganic [Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n 4+ network templated by 5-ATZ anions. 2b exhibits the 3D metal-organic framework with a (8.122)(84.122)(42.124) topology. Among them, the coordination number of the 5-HATZ ligand varies from one for 1a and 2a to three and four for 1b and 2b; the hydrogen atom attached to the tetrazole ring of the 5-HATZ can be deprotonated at higher temperature. The connectivity of the sulfate anion varies from the μ2- to the μ5-bridged mode. These results show that the increase of reaction temperature leads to higher connectivity of the ligands and higher dimensions of the ultimate structures. Complex 1b exhibits blue emission in the solid state, while no significant emission is found in 1a. Both 1b and 2b exhibit significantly higher thermal stability than that of 1a and 2a.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two pairs of Cd(II)-5-aminotetrazolate coordination polymers from 1D to 3D materials were successfully isolated in this study. 1a and 2a are 1D chains synthesized by the solution evaporation method at room temperature, while 1b and 2b are 3D frameworks synthesized under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. 1b is constructed by 3D inorganic [Cd5(μ5-SO4)2(μ3-OH)2] n  4+ network templated by 5-ATZ anions. 2b exhibits the 3D metal-organic framework with a (8.122)(84.122)(42.124) topology. Among them, the coordination number of the 5-HATZ ligand varies from one for 1a and 2a to three and four for 1b and 2b; the hydrogen atom attached to the tetrazole ring of the 5-HATZ can be deprotonated at higher temperature. The connectivity of the sulfate anion varies from the μ2- to the μ5-bridged mode. These results show that the increase of reaction temperature leads to higher connectivity of the ligands and higher dimensions of the ultimate structures. Complex 1b exhibits blue emission in the solid state, while no significant emission is found in 1a. Both 1b and 2b exhibit significantly higher thermal stability than that of 1a and 2a.

cln_elements.content:
An aqueous solution (10 mL) of 3CdSO4·8H2O (0.77 g, 1 mmol) was added into an aqueous solution (50 mL) of 5-HATZ (0.51 g, 6 mmol) with stirring at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting solution was filtered, and left to evaporate. After a week, colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractrion were obtained (0.30 g, yield 70% based on 3CdSO4·8H2O). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C2H12CdN10O7S: C, 5.55; H, 2.77; N, 32.36%. Found: C, 5.39; H, 2.88; N, 31.64%. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3397 s, 3318 m, 3208 m, 3123 m, 1652 s, 1577 m, 1441 m, 1292 m, 1188 m, 1115 m, 1059 m, 1006 w, 765 w, 724 m, 678 w, 619 m, 437 m.

Synthesis of [Cd<sub>5</sub>(5-ATZ)<sub>4</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-OH)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>5</sub>-SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1b</bold>)

Compound 1b was synthesized from compound 1a (0.15 g) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor (10 mL water), under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1b were obtained (0.05 g, yield: 64% based on Cd(II) in 1a). Anal. Calcd for C4H10Cd5N20O10S2: C, 4.27; H, 0.90; N, 24.91%. Found: C, 4.13; H, 1.05; N, 24.38%. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3424 m, 3341 m, 3233 w, 1644 m, 1624 m, 1557 s, 1545 s, 1437 m, 1420 m, 1279 m, 1254 m, 1123 s, 1076 m, 989 m, 894 m, 798 m, 773 m, 744 m, 613 s, 459 m. Compound 1b can also be obtained by direct mixture of 3CdSO4·8H2O (0.08 g, 0.1 mmol) and 5-HATZ (0.03 g, 0.3 mmol) under the hydrothermal condition with 45% based on metal salts.

Synthesis of [Cd(5-HATZ)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>2</sub>-Cl)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2a</bold>)

A mixture of CdCl2·2.5H2O (0.46 g, 2 mmol), 5-HATZ (0.34 g, 4 mmol), MeCN (10 mL), and water (30 mL) was stirred for 4 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was filtered and then left to evaporate. After a week, colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffracion were obtained (0.27 g, yield 75% based on CdCl2·2.5H2O). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C2H6CdCl2N10: C, 6.80; H, 1.71; N, 39.63%. Found: C, 6.09; H, 2.70; N, 38.88%. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3396 s, 3319 s, 3209 m, 3086 s, 1652 s, 1577 m, 1448 m, 1297 m, 1155 m, 1094 m, 1064 m, 1015 m, 786 m, 732 m, 686 m, 516 w, 439 m, 416 m.

Synthesis of [Cd<sub>3</sub>(5-ATZ)<sub>4</sub>(MeCN)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>2</sub>-Cl)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2b</bold>)

Compound 2b was synthesized from compound 2a (0.10 g) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor (2.5 mL MeCN, 7.5 mL water), under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 2b were obtained (0.06 g, yield: 38% based on Cd(II) in 2a). Anal. Calcd for C8H14Cd3Cl2N22: C, 11.63; H, 1.71; N, 37.28%. Found: C, 10.97; H, 2.05; N, 36.44%. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3444 s, 3342 s, 2300 m, 2271 m, 1653 m, 1620 s, 1556 s, 1462 m, 1438 s, 1283 m, 1163 m, 1130 m, 1084 m, 1014 m, 753 m, 450 m. Compound 2b can also be obtained by direct mixture of CdCl2·2.5H2O (0.05 g, 0.2 mmol) and 5-HATZ (0.04 g, 0.4 mmol) under the hydrothermal condition with 31% based on metal salts.

An aqueous solution (10 mL) of 3CdSO4⋅8H2O (0.77 g, 1 mmol) was added into an aqueous solution (50 mL) of 5-HATZ (0.51 g, 6 mmol) with stirring at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting solution was filtered, and left to evaporate. After a week, colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractrion were obtained (0.30 g, yield 70% based on 3CdSO4⋅8H2O). Compound 1b was synthesized from compound 1a (0.15 g) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor (10 mL water), under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1b were obtained (0.05 g, yield: 64% based on Cd(II) in 1a). Anal. Calcd for C4H10Cd5N20O10S2: C, 4.27; H, 0.90; N, 24.91%. Found: C, 4.13; H, 1.05; N, 24.38%. cln_elements.content: Thermogravimeric analysis of 1a (Figure ) shows 12.3% weight loss between room temperature and 147 °C, in agreement with the corresponding calculated values of 12.5%, due to the loss of water molecules. The distinction between weight losses from the coordinated and noncoordinated water was not clearly demonstrated in TGA data. The relatively low temperature for loss of coordinated water molecules demonstrates their weak coordination. Then the continuous weight loses above 195 °C correspond to the continuous decomposition of 5-HATZ ligands and anions. For 2a, there is no weight loss from room temperature to 258 °C, and after that, it begins to decompose quickly. Compared with 1a and 2a, 3D complexes 1b and 2b exhibit remarkable higher thermalstability. The TGA study of 1b shows no weight loss from room temperature to 390 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. Above 390 °C, the weight loss is due to the collapse of the framework. Furthermore, the high density value (ρ = 3.392 g/cm3) also supports the high thermal stability of the 3D framework. The TGA data for 2b indicates the first weight loss occurs at ca. 239 °C and the second started at ca. 358 °C. For all complexes, complete decomposition is not achieved above 600 °C. The TGA results show that normally the 1D complexes are more unstable than 3D complexes, and the 3D complexes normally show high robustness for the coordination networks, which is consistent with the previous reported result. The simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 2b are shown in a and . They are in good agreement with each other, which prove the phase purity of the as-synthesized product. The results of a series of varied temperature PXRD of 2b from 100 to 300 °C exhibit no phase transformation and the coordination network variety ().

Thermal Properties and PXRD

Thermogravimeric analysis of 1a (Figure ) shows 12.3% weight loss between room temperature and 147 °C, in agreement with the corresponding calculated values of 12.5%, due to the loss of water molecules. The distinction between weight losses from the coordinated and noncoordinated water was not clearly demonstrated in TGA data. The relatively low temperature for loss of coordinated water molecules demonstrates their weak coordination. Then the continuous weight loses above 195 °C correspond to the continuous decomposition of 5-HATZ ligands and anions. For 2a, there is no weight loss from room temperature to 258 °C, and after that, it begins to decompose quickly. Compared with 1a and 2a, 3D complexes 1b and 2b exhibit remarkable higher thermalstability. The TGA study of 1b shows no weight loss from room temperature to 390 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. Above 390 °C, the weight loss is due to the collapse of the framework. Furthermore, the high density value (ρ = 3.392 g/cm3) also supports the high thermal stability of the 3D framework. The TGA data for 2b indicates the first weight loss occurs at ca. 239 °C and the second started at ca. 358 °C. For all complexes, complete decomposition is not achieved above 600 °C. The TGA results show that normally the 1D complexes are more unstable than 3D complexes, and the 3D complexes normally show high robustness for the coordination networks, which is consistent with the previous reported result. The simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 2b are shown in a and . They are in good agreement with each other, which prove the phase purity of the as-synthesized product. The results of a series of varied temperature PXRD of 2b from 100 to 300 °C exhibit no phase transformation and the coordination network variety ().
